Award.AwardTitle: AitF: FULL: Collaborative Research: Optimizing Networked Systems with Limited Information

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past decades, the world's dominant computational infrastructure has gradually transitioned from individual personal computers to massive networked systems of unprecedented scale and complexity. Not only has this led to tremendous technological and engineering challenges, but it has also called into question fundamental assumptions in classical algorithmic theory. A defining distinction is the limited information that algorithms in such decentralized and heterogeneous systems have access to. For example, a content delivery network serves a heterogeneous set of end devices, and has to optimize performance often without knowledge of the device it is optimizing for. Similarly, a data center scheduler must be optimized for future demands that it is oblivious to. In this project, the PIs seek to address novel algorithmic questions in non-clairvoyant models of computation that arise in real world networked systems. The successful completion of this project will lead to new advances in building reliable and resilient information networks. The project will enable collaborations and exchange of ideas between theoreticians and practitioners, and will provide extensive training in real world algorithms to several graduate students, with attention paid to gender diversity and participation of under-represented groups.

The goal of the project is to design novel algorithms with provable guarantees for networked systems in limited information settings. In particular, the PIs plan to address key algorithmic problems in the three dominant computational infrastructure models in the Internet: (a) data centers: allocating parallelizable jobs requiring multiple resources on processing nodes and clusters; (b) wide-area network of clusters: long-term planning of resource deployment and synergistic operations in the client-server model; and (c) P2P browser clouds: content delivery in web and gaming applications and swarm computing on a fabric of a large number of loosely coupled unreliable browsers. These problem domains are characterized by uncertainty and limited information for several reasons, including uncertainty about future predictions, autonomy of individual components in the networked system, and distributed implementation of the network architecture. The algorithms designed as part of this project will be evaluated on and optimized for real world testbeds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the course of the project, several lines of research were pursued.

 

The first line of research focused on algorithms for data center networks. In particular, questions around denial-of-service attacks due to malicious traffic patterns and distributing resource-specific jobs to particular clusters/locations to optimize use of the data center network capacity were studied. The project formulated these as optimization problems and designed approximately optimal algorithms for these problems.

 

The second line of research focused on bridging the gap between theory and practice in terms of precision of input in network algorithms. While in theory the norm is to optimize for precise, specific inputs, the situation in practice is often that one is optimizing with predicted input values (such as future demands) which come as a range of possible inputs. The project introduced an algorithmic framework for studying such problems using dual parameters of approximation and regret, and obtained nearly tight bounds on these problems in this framework.

 

The third line of research focused on network routing in practical settings. In particular, routing and scheduling algorithms were developed for applications ranging from controlling robots in fulfillment centers for online retailers to dispatching in ride hailing services. These solutions were then tested on real world data sets to evaluate their performance in practice, and were found to substantially improve on baseline solutions. Part of this research was done in collaboration with Google researchers.

 

The fourth line of research focused on designing algorithms for the sharing economy. In particular, the goal was to understand group formation dynamics in decentralized settings such as ridesharing, MOOCs, etc. This problem was considered in a variety of settings that included submodular and supermodular utility functions of the participating agents. New equilibrium characterizations, and incentive structures that foster collaboration and group formation, were developed. 

 

The fifth line of research focused on the design of auctions in limited information settings. Multi-unit auctions, combinatorial auctions, and first price auctions were studied. The main thrust of this research was to formalize the basic concept of incentive compatiblity in auctions when the agents do not have complete information. This research complements the rich body of work that studies incentice compatible auctions in the classic, full information setting.

 

The project provided funding for several PhD students at Duke University. In addition, it helped foster collaborations between the PIs and researchers at Google and Facebook. Finally, it led to closer collaboration between Duke and Northeastern University, the two universities participating in the project.
